title: Arduino Uno mount for Glasswalkers Revised Fully Printable Eggbot

description.text: A mount for Arduino Uno electronics for Glasswalkers Revised Fully Printable Eggbot

Version 0.2.5... or something like that anyway... I'm happy with it, it fits the Eggbot and the Arduino so can't say fairer than that! Looks nicer IMHO than its previous iterations too.
Fixed the hole positioning although that may have been a bit pointless as the hole in question is the one near the 6 pin header, too close for a screw head.
Print the stl and you will have a mount and 4 spacers.
Fit the mount to the rear 8mm threaded rods, fit M3 screws, spacers and the Arduino Uno and secure with M3 nuts.

I searched "spool holder" on Thingiverse, it found 6,881, but couldn't decide which one I liked the best... :o)
I realize designing & printing a spool holder is kind of a "Right of Passage", But I suffer from a paucity of counter space & don't want to attach a spool holder to my new Kossel Delta mini. So, I decided to go with a carpenters way - two closet shelf/rod brackets mounted above and behind the printer with a 1" PVC pipe in the rod hooks.
Normally I would attach the brackets to a couple of studs, but this location has a window.
So, I am mounting the brackets to the back of a heavy base cabinet I made from a sixty year old three panel door. Brackets are 10" apart with a 16" piece of 1" schedule 40 PVC pipe. It has slots cut to keep it from spinning & centered. If I were mounting the brackets on 16" centers I would put a piece of broom stick inside the pipe to keep it from sagging.
Oh, I only looked at about 100 of the spool holder designs, so this may not be new. DB
The rocket is my Angus 1 "FuseD Muse" model in honor of my favorite 3DP channel host.
see - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2410397

title: Atelier Shallie Shallistera Bell Prop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model of Shallistera Argo's bell prop from Atelier Shallie (see included reference art). It's split into two main parts: the bell and the handle.

Connect the bell and the handle with a rod a bit smaller than 1/4"; I used a 3/16" fiberglass rod and epoxied it into the holes on each side. Stiffness is important, so don't use something weak, and make sure the parts are oriented correctly (rotationally) when you glue it, or else you'll regret it ;-)

I split the handle into four parts to print; I included the split parts if you'd like to just use those. I glued it together with superglue and epoxy and finished with XTC-3D + Modern Metals Gold + hand paints and a gloss finish. The finish was chosen in part to be fairly durable, as from experience with my previous bell, it tends to get easily banged and scratched up a lot at conventions, so a damage-resistant finish is preferable to something slightly shinier but fragile.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bell should be printable without supports despite the overhang if your bridging is good (and intentionally, the mess will be on the inside, where it doesn't matter!). This could probably be done better in some fashion, but I didn't feel like it mattered.

I only used supports for the two bigger handle pieces, in order to get the side-guard to print better.

TR
Yeni versiyona bir göz atın:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551717

Daha az vidanın daha az titreşime sebep olacağı düşüncesiyle bu dizaynı yaptım
NOTLAR:
Nozül fanı sola alındığı için arta kalan yere e3d alınmıştır. Bu yüzden nozül ucu 20mm geriye gelmiştir. Bu taşıyıcıyı kullanmanız halinde ısıtıcı tablayı da 20mm geriye almanız gerekebilir.
Ayrıca nozül fan ucu olarak 5 farklı uzunlukta model mevcut. e3d clamp'in alt kısmı ile nozül ucu arası mesafeyi ölçerek ilgili resim ile karşılaştırınız. Resimdeki uzunluk (20,3mm) benim yazıcıma ait olup ben fan ucu olarak 43mm olanı kullanmaktayım. Kendi ölçtüğünüz uzunluğa uygun olanı seçiniz.
X taşıyıcı parçası düz kenarı üzerinde olacak şekilde yan basılmalıdır. Basarken desteğe ihtiyaç yoktur.

EN
Check out the new version:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551717

Less screws and less noise. This thought gave me the idea of designing this carriage.
NOTES:
Please be aware that because the nozzle fan is moved to the side of the carriage, nozzle tip is moved bacwards for 20mm. So you should move the heated bed 20mm backwards too after istallation of this carriage.
Also there are 5 lenghts of fan shroud. I put a picture of my printer that shows the distance from the bottom of the e3d clamp to the nozzle tip (20,3mm). I am using 43mm one. In case of variances for your printer, please measure this distance and print the proper one for you.
X carriage part should be printed on its flat side without any need of support.

title: Fully 3D Printable Swappable Target Dueling Tree for Paintball Or Airsoft Target Practice

description.text: I tried to make the targets interchangeable so you only needed one removable arm, but while creating, the arm didn't seem to fit in the targets despite correct measurements. So I made an arm permanently attached to each size of target, and put the targets in separate files so you can just print the size(s) you want. The "mount" is the main part that the target attaches to and spins it 180 degrees. It attaches to a piece of PVC pipe as the pole with screws screwed through the 4 holes on the bottom of the mount.

title: Anet A8 E3d v6 tronxy sensor mount RIGHT

description.text:
This is another Remix from Achmed20. Seems to have good stuff.

This mount looked real good. Nice and close to the extruder. Also very simple. The only problem was my cooling fan is where is has the sensor. So I simply Mirrored it. That's all. Just a RIGHT hand version of the original.

Here are the specs from the original from Achmed20's post Keep in mind the sensor is on the other side so it will have to be tweaked...:

Anet A8 Marlin / Skynet settings
Here are the settings for marlin / Skynet thast work with my mashine. be careful with the
"Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER ".

Y axis is smaller then Stock because tech2c's holder sits way more in the front then the stock printhead.

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -18 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -2 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

define X_MAX_POS 240

define X_MIN_POS -20

define Y_MAX_POS 195

define Y_MIN_POS -30

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 25

define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 215

define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190

define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15

title: USO : Unidentified Storage Object
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
USO's exist... Unidentified Storage Object's (with an outer disk section that rotates) have started invading build plates all around the world!

The images provided are proof USO's exist...

This is fun and practical storage solution in the shape of a UFO. The USO disk is made of two parts (upper and lower) and link together to rotate around the central body part. Use a light (silicone) lubricant on all the contacting surfaces to ensure your USO disk rotates freely and threads run smoothly together / apart.

A fully assembled a USO printed at standard scale is approx. 125mm in diameter and 75mm in height. Make one just as a fun model UFO or use it as a novel storage container for all sorts of small things. There are seven (7) storage areas inside the USO, one of which is a 'secret chamber' underneath (the screw in base part is hollow). However, unless you know better, to a casual observer seeing the USO on a shelf / desk, they would think it was just a model... and not suspect anything is stored inside.

The USO design is made five (5) parts. One of each part is required. They are easy PLA prints 'without support' on precise, well set up machines. Accuracy is essential so the threads that hold parts together form well and clearances are adequate but not excessive.

Note: An alternative Top has been added which has two small holes in it so the USO can be easily hung up and displayed. The alternative Top file is named 'hang top.stl'

Make a USO as a fun model / display thing or to use for storage. USO's will look great in all sorts of colours. You can also pause your machine mid print (at approx. 1mm height...so very early in the print) to add a coloured ring around the upper disk for a spacey effect. The base looks good printed in a different colour from the body and disk parts (refer images).

Scaling up / down should be okay but do not scale down too far or the clearances will reduce too much to the extent that the parts will not fit together and threads not screw together.

Please refer to the images and print instructions for additional information... and post images of your USO's for other members to see!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Atandard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% infill

Notes:

The USO parts are all easy prints provided you have a well set up / precise slicing app and machine. Good build plate adhesion is important as is a filament fan providing effective cooling to deal with the extreme angles applied.

Key points / recommendations are:

Using a Raft is recommended to improve build plate adhesion

Print each file in the orientation as provided (in the download). The lower disk, body and top all print upside down from how they will be oriented once assembled.

Do not use any automated support. If your machine is well set up, build plate adhesion is good, and you have effective filament cooling support is not necessary

Your USO is ready to assemble...

Firstly clean up away any stringing and print imperfections. Next, it is strongly recommended that you apply a light (silicone) lubricant to all the threads and surfaces that will run against each other when the disk parts (upper and lower) are rotating around the body.

Before final assembly test the threads run together fully, make sure the disk parts interlock easily and that the interlocked disk parts rotate around the body part.

Now you are ready for final assembly... which is easy!

Slide the lower disk onto the body... followed by the upper disk. Check the two disk parts have interlocked so they will only move together once held in place then screw the cap on top. Provided your USO has printed well the disk should rotate around the body. Lastly, screw the base up into the body from underneath.

The designed in clearances (at standard scale) should be snug but not tight. The aim is to ensure this design works reliably across most makes / model machines. However, some may find the clearances looser or tighter than is ideal when printed on your machine. Minor uniform scaling will usually overcome this issue.

To add items to be stored / remove items stored inside just unscrew the top cap and lift off the top disk.... and unscrew the base to add/ remove things from underneath.

comments.text: I love these Gears... I'm now using them on my Ormerod Z axis drive as they are perfect. It took me a couple of goes to get them right, which highlighted problems I hadn't noticed with my machine, but I've since corrected. If you print these and have problems. Look at your belts and ensure you have them running correctly, as well as the angle of your Z axis, as the gears are such a good fit, that they demand that the machine is running correctly. My Z axis had shifted by a few degrees and I hadn't noticed. Meshing the finished gears, and putting a steel rule across their base showed up the problem. Once corrected, I have a set of perfect working gears that run like silk.. Thanks for the hard work Iamburny..

description.text:
I was looking for a SIMPLE mount that I could attach to my quads with 3M tape. LOTS of mounts out there, but most are the wrong angle (for me), have some kind of BS embossed logo or someone's name, or are intended only for one specific frame.

These are generic 22 degree mounts that can be used on pretty much ANY frame. If you don't like something, or want a different angle, I'm including the source files (SolidWorks) that you can modify to your heart's content.

The two mounts are virtually identical. The only difference is the "inverted" one, designed to mount under the quad, has a semi-circular cutout to accommodate the lens. Other than that, they are the same. You could actually use the "Inverted" one on top if the cutout in the back doesn't bother you.

Attach to your frame with 3M tape - no zip ties necessary. I've never had one fall off. You can attach your Runcam, Runcam2 or Mobius with a velcro strip (shown), or with a simple zip tie. I've used both and have had no problems.

Enjoy!

description.text:
I've noticed in my Intex pool that the outlet is releasing the water straight out in the front and this lead to a non optimized water movement as on the outlet left a swirl is forming that is trapping some dirt and never releases, on the front an irregular movement is found and on the right the water is correctly going to the inlet (see the two water flux images).

This could be much optimized... so this modified outlet was born!

This outlet replaces the standard Intex one you've got with the pool. You'll be pleased with the result!

Please share your experience or if you have suggestions and don't forget to post a print of your new bended outlet at work!!! :)

Many thanks goes to Matthew Redmon that designed an outlet adapter that inspired me and gave me a start: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1649784
I've started modifying some of his openscad code but, after having print the first prototype, I've seen that the thread was not correct and the diameter was some millimeters too big, so the outlet had no chance to stay there.
I then decided to rewrite the whole thing from scratch. And that was nice even for exercice on openscad ;)

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Pay attention to the threaded ring, I suggest to print it with something like -0.3mm XY size compensation to be sure that it will not have too much friction with the inner thread. Much depends on the precision of your printer... I've printed the inner part with -0.2 and the outer with -0.4 but you have to try with your printer.
I suggest to print the inner part and then print some trials with the threaded ring, as it's very fast to print.
That will make you know how much XY size compensation to use for the biggest part too.
I've used -0.3 with my New Matter MOD-t.

I've included the STL pre rendered objects ready to slice and the openscad file if you want to change something or use it as a base for something different. Use what you like most!

I've designed the base (biggest object) with openscad as there where no way to find the correct Intex outlet thread in Fusion 360 so I've used the (very good!) ISOThreadUM2 thread library by Trevor Moseley to create a customized one.
That was useful even for the knurled surface, very easy with another good library: knurledFinishLib by aubenc that you can find here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095
I'm actually loving the printed result!!!
The upper swirl and threaded ring where designed with Fusion 360, using one of the standard thread that was more close to the size I needed.

comments.text: Thanks for making this!  I'm going to test it out!
comments.author: neo302

comments.text: I'm happy that this model could be useful to other people :) Please reply here how the test was as there is the doubt that Intex has slightly different outlet threads... And a big thank you if you post a picture in the "made" section ;)
comments.author: neo302

comments.text:
I'm having trouble getting the ring on. Should it be extremely tight?
Thanks
comments.author: energywave

comments.text: Not really. I've printed it with some negative XY size compensation as my printer is not calibrated (and cannot be...). I suggest to reprint the ring with higher negative XY size compensation until it get on without too much friction. The ring should be very fast to reprint and waste very little filament. I've used -0.2 for the spout and -0.3 for the ring, if I remember correctly.
comments.author: neo302

comments.text:
I grew the ring X & Y to 50.5MM and it fits the stock angled spout perfect.
The main body does not fit my blue intex parts (too tight), but a gray intex like spout I have fit, but it is tight.
Overall it is good to go! Thanks again!
comments.author: energywave

comments.text:
Maybe you have the other dimension as the user here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1649784 from where I was inspired to make this model.
He was using a thread diameter of 84mm while for my intex spout was too big (thread dents didn't even touch). I measured with the caliper and the correct size for me was 81.25mm, wich is the size I've used in my design. I did even measured thread pitch with a thread counter (don't know if it's the right english name...) and was exactly 2.5mm.
Could your diameter be 84mm? Or it's a matter of some decimals?

description.text:
The original design that I remixed and all credit for this is by CH35C0, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149867

I redesigned this as the Screw had to be scaled down in most cases to fit the plate.

The changes that I made where the pitch of the thread & clearance, the length of the screw body and the head of screw.

The main body of the Y tensioner is the one designed by CH35C0.

My goal was to be able to print this without having to find the correct scale to make it work. Thread is a M10 x 1.25, I shrunk the thread of the screw by 0.02mm to give it a little extra clearance in the original design in Fusion 360 and to help with the fit of the plate when printed.

The plate has a standard M10 x 1.25 thread.

title: Raise3D N2 electronics cooling intake duct

description.text:
This is a remix for printability.
I tried every orientation to print wibbcat's two-part duct, and when I finally got a good print (standing vertical), the two pieces would not fit together.
So this is a merge of the original two pieces. It prints diagonally across the print bed on one edge as shown, with the "snorkel" side closest to the build plate. I used supports only under the "snorkel" part. It took about 20 hours, but fits nicely.
I tried using some foam to seal the fan intake to the donut flange, but the fan bogged down, so this is apparently only going to take in a small percentage of cooler air to the electronics. However, that does make it miles more effective than the OEM cooling setup.

Once the epoxy cures use acetone to chemically weld the two halves together. .

author: Ratm3at

title: Canon EOS / EF adapter for Logitech C260 webcamera

description.text:
An adapter to attach a Logitech C260 webcam to Canon EOS (EF / EF-S) lenses. It replaces the front panel of the camera. I also include separate files just for the front panel of C260, and just for the female Canon EOS adapter - they should make it easier creating similar adapters for other mounts. Both STL and the original (SketchUp) files are included.

If you use the SketchUp file to remaster the model, make sure to Explode All at the end, and get rid of the two internal surfaces (e.g. by running it through the Solid Inspector plugin).

As my measurement of the distance to the C260 sensor is not precise (it's accurate to ~0.25mm), and also because individual printers might print the adapter's height with some inaccuracy (say ~0.2mm), this adapter will likely not be useful for wide angle lenses without some fine tuning (as they are much more sensitive to the register distance accuracy). You should probably be okay for focal lengths >= 50mm. It works well with my Canon 70-200 F4L.

This might also work for other similar Logitech cameras (like C270 etc) - you'll have to test it yourself.

The primary goal of this modification is to be able to use C260 for astrophotography. I can now either attach it to my Canon 70-200 f4L lens, and use it as an auto-guiding camera for my 6" Celestron reflector, or attach it to the Celestron using an EOS-telescope adapter. In the latter case, the camera can be used as an autoguider using my telescope as a guide, or can be used for taking Moon/planetary shots in the prime focus of my telescope.

I printed it using Cura, with the EOS adapter side down, using "supports everywhere" option, 0.2mm layers, and 100% infill. Make sure to use a slower printing speed for both outer and inner walls.

It'd be a good idea at the end to sand the inside of the adapter, and then paint the inside with black acrylic paint - this should eliminate the stray light.

comments.text: I can't see how this would work as an autogider as it has no way to control the scope but this is perfect for doing planetary work. Great job.

comments.text: To make this an autoguiding camera, one has to attach it to a lens (Canon 70-400 f4L in my case), attach the lens to a telescope with a robotic mount (Celestron CG5 for me), and then connect both the telescope and the camera to a laptop running an autoguiding software (PHD2).

I could never get the hole for the screw where I actually needed it using Tinkercad, (sorry, still learning how to use it), so I used a small drill bit to make the hole. You could also put a small hole in the front, but I didn't as it was a snug fit. All I did was put super glue on both the foot part with the screw and the round part, and it works fine. The final print was in black to match and I used ABS @ 50% infill.

Base case for the Tronxy X1 to make it truly portable. It will require a larger printer to print however as it is all one piece. The base of the X1 fits right into the top. To mount I used a pilot bit and drilled through the base of the X1 into the flange of the case with a bit smaller then the screws I used. Then I drilled through the base of the X1 pilot holes only with a larger bit and then screwed the base of the printer to the case. I put in some LED lighting to give it an added touch.

author: jstark0820

print_settings.Notes:: 3 shells

description.text:
D Moews sent me a zip file containing code that constructs slide adders like those due to Kummer and Troncet.
http://history-computer.com/MechanicalCalculators/19thCentury/Kummer.html
http://history-computer.com/CalculatingTools/Gadgets/Troncet.html.
The 3 stl files assemble into an adding machine.

Part of the README that comes with the zip file is shown below; the complete README file with all references is included. D. Moews has placed the zip file in the public domain. It is available for download at: http://djm.cc/slide-adder-0.03.zip

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

3 shells

Contents

This set of OpenSCAD files constructs a slide adder with a curved guide which permits manual carries to be made easily. These sorts of calculators are often called "addiators", after the company Addiator, which manufactured a number of them, or Troncet-type, after Louis Troncet, who constructed an adder called the Arithmographe which worked this way. The adder consists of a series of strips sliding in a tray, with a lid on top. ...

Operation

The running total of the adder is displayed in the windows. To add a new number into the total, you should proceed from right to left. Starting in the rightmost column, place a stylus or other object in the aperture (hole or slot) in the strip next to the digit marked on the lid corresponding to the digit in the number you wish to add to the total. If the aperture in the strip is a hole, move the stylus downwards until the hole is next to the digit marked 0 on the lid. If the aperture in the strip is a slot, move the stylus upwards, pushing on the tab above the slot, until the lower edge of the tab above the stylus is level with the top edge of the aperture in the lid. Then, move the stylus to the left and downwards so that it contacts the upper side of the tab in the left portion of the aperture in the lid, and move this tab down until its upper edge is level with the bottom edge of the left portion of the aperture in the lid.

After addition is completed, you may find a plus sign ("+") displayed in some window. If the plus sign is not in the leftmost column, it may be cleared by performing the steps in the previous paragraph corresponding to adding the digit 0. This may generate another plus sign in the next column to the left, which can then be cleared in the same way, and so on. If the plus sign is in the leftmost column, it corresponds to the digit 0 together with a carry out of the leftmost column, and cannot be cleared.

History

A slide adder with a curved guide like that of this device was designed by Heinrich Kummer (b. 1809, Dresden; d. 1880, Dresden.) He presented his adder to the Russian Academy of Sciences on 4 September 1846. Kummer's adder was patented in Russia, France, and the U.S.

Louis Troncet also designed an adder like this, one of his various adders named "Arithmographe". It was patented in France in 1889 and was commercially successful. In the 20th century, adders of this type were widely manufactured and marketed by the German firm Addiator.

title: Flight Controller Mount for C1 Chaser Wing

description.text:
I designed this part to make it easy and a very solid attachment to put a flight controller in the C1 Chaser Wing from Banggood. I'm initially using a SPRacing F3 mini but Later I will be installing an Omnubus F4 V2 or V3 flight controller.

Once printed, use a M3 screw (same as most multi-rotor motors and frames use) to cut the threads for the standoffs to screw in the part. Alternatively you can drill the holes out and use an M3 bolt up from the bottom if you like. If cutting threads just try to keep the screw perpendicular to the part so that the standoffs will screw straight up and down into the part.

This mount is to be glued to the foam in the center section.

Printer:

Monoproce Select Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13125

Infill:

25% 'lines'

Notes:

I need to rotate the model 45 degrees to make it printable on the Select Mini's 120x120 bed. Other than this it's pretty straight forward and just prints flat. I printed it in PETG but other materials should be fine too.

I did a bunch of measuring and printing about 7 different parts before settling on this design. I may design another part to mount a FC behind the spar so that the FC tray in not in the way of larger battery options for the C1 Chaser.

The reason I chose to put the FC forward of the spar is that it is closer to the CG.

title: Anet A8 X Belt holder and tensionner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you love this design and it help you, consider tipping me as I spent a good amount of time on this design. Thanks in advance ! ( First tipper at 6944 download : JustenC !!! Thank you so much ! )

Remixed Kenneth Jiang version to add a tensionner on the setup. There is a screw ( M3x30 that come with the Anet ) that go thru the body and attach to the nut that with in the tighter.

You install the belt, as shown in the picture and then you tighten the belt with the screw.

I wanted to use the lenght of the x_belt you end up with after the first built of the Anet. It was too short for most of the tensionner. This one fit perfect and you can get the belt pretty darn tight. I ended up loosing it up a bit to not put too much force on the Z axis.

File to print

  • you need one tighter part
  • for the body, measure your belt, dimensions are as follow
    -- body : 1.65mm toothed groove and 2.35mm folded groove
    -- thin belt : 1.5mm toothed groove and 2.2mm folded groove
    -- gates fiberglass : 1.3mm toothed groove and 2mm folded groove

V2

I added a little more structure to the upper part. Also revised the tooth a little They are still pretty darn tight and I have to push the belt with a little screw driver to get to the bottom of the groove. Might be a good thing though, as I definitly don't want any play here.

V3

First thanks for the comments and likes it's appreciated !

I had a failure of the tighter part. It just broke at the nut. So I went back and increased the size of the section were it broke. Hopefully now it will be correct. I'll print a second one as a spare if it break again.

  • Increased the space for the tooths and now the belt slide in easy enough, but is still snug.
  • Rotated the stl so that the correct print orientation is native. No more turning the part for print.
  • Removed one screw that was basically useless and was just adding weight to the carriage.
  • With the new orientation, I didn't had issue with the slide portion, so didn't changed this one. It is still very snug, but that's what you want !
  • Added a version for thin belt as when I upgraded my GT2 belt, the new one with fiberglass core was thinner than the steelcore that come with the Anet. It slipped and I wasn't able to thight the belt.

V4

  • I've narrowed a little bit the thin belt version. Now toothed groove is 1.5mm and folded groove 2.2mm
  • With recommendation of bASHer91 I've also uploaded an even thinner design for gate fibercore belt which is 1.3mm and 2mm respectively.

Print service

My Print service can be found there : https://www.treatstock.com/3d-printing-services/miranio-printing

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35

Notes:

Tighter infill : 100%
Body infill : 25%

Suports for the tighter : non-required
Supports for the body : REQUIRED with supports roof

fit between the slider and the body is very thight. Usually dimensions on 3d prints are made with 0.2mm clearance minimum and this is what it was designed with. I didn't have to file it, you might have to file a little bit. It is by design very thigh as this is what you want, you definitly don't want any play in a part that hold the belt very thight.

title: Adjustable Printrbot Simple XL Tower Filament Tray Expansion

description.text:
An adjustable spool holder to swap between different sized filament spools in an instant. Allows 74mm (Original PrintrBot Spool) to 110mm wide spools to be used. Update
For more stability I added an extension inspired by thing
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221509 and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162699 140308 - Second Update
Added new parts to allow for spools down to 64mm width (and up to 120mm ;).
The new parts are named '_Narrow' and '_Wide' respectively. I have not printed these new parts but they should work as the fundamentals are unchanged.

VITAMINS: 4 16mm M3 screws
2 30mm M3 screws OPTIONAL VITAMINS: 2 20mm M5 screws
4 M5 washers TOOLS: Printrbot Simple with extended bed
M3 HSS twist drill threaded bit Exact Thread
2,5 mm Allen wrench OPTIONAL TOOLS: 3mm Twist Drill Bit
5mm Twist Drill Bit
Rotary Tool
Round Needle File
Medium Toothed File INSTRUCTIONS: All prints were done on my Simple XL Tower with extended bed using 0.25 mm layer height. All parts prints with skirt. The spool holder with 3mm roller bearing mount was created as courtesy to those who want to use the original screws and have not been tested as I use the M5 screws myself. When the parts are printed use the M3 HSS twist drill threaded bit exact thread to thread the narrow screw holes. Dependent on print quality and the selection of spool holder part printed you may have to drill out the roller bearing holes. 3mm for the original screw or 5mm hole for the optional M5 screw. The original M4 screw should fit in the 3mm hole, if not ream the hole slightly with a needle file. If necessary, use a medium toothed file to get rid of the slightly wider bottom layer to give the rails a snug fit. Mount the ball bearings using either the original M4 screw and washers as per the original instructions or the new spool holder M5 screw with one washer on each side of the spool holder frame. Mount the rails with two M3 screws on each side of the spool holder. Dismount the original right spool holder. Mount the tray extension with 2 30mm M3 screws. Slide the new spool holder in place while bending the spring clips slightly. Begin with the the longer in front and then the shorter rear spring clip.

title: Modular Tevo Tarantula Dual Extruder X Carriage for MGN12H Linear Rail

description.text:
This is an X carriage for the Tevo Tarantula with dual extruder option.  It is designed to be mounted on an MGN12H block on a linear guide rail.  Make sure you get a block that has the same spacing as an MGN12H block (20mm distance between mounting holes).

  The belt is attached to the lower portion only and the upper portion screws on top of it (through it and into the MGN12H block).  This allows the upper portion that holds the hotend, endstop, fans to be removed without detaching the belt. I designed it this way because I intend to have several different versions of the upper part to hold a single extruder or to hold other hotends.

  Lastly, the top part has intentionally been left clear so as to accomodate other parts that can be bolted on later. I am currently working on cable management attachments that take advantage of this feature. It can also be used to attach fans, lights, etc.

If you're interested in a single extruder version message me and if there's enough interest I'll make one.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make sure your printer is calibrated correctly specially in the X and Y axes to ensure that the screw holes line up.

title: Dadcubed Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I recently found out Dadcubed got a 3D printer and I decided I would make his logo 3D printable. This took me about an hour to make. I am so excited to see Dadcubed get into 3D printing. I feel like he is going to fall in love with it.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Everything sliced very well in Cura.

The print took about 40 minutes at 80mm/s.

This was printed in Microcenters 1.75mm Inland PLA at 200C with a bed temp of 50C.

Creating the Image

The first thing I did was download his logo from his YouTube channel art then use GIMP to trim the banner to where it left only his logo with the background being transparency.

Next, I used http://svg2stl.com to vectorize the image.

Next, I used Inkscape to split the white and orange into to separate svg files.

Creating the Model

To create the model I used Tinkercad to import the svg into a 3D environment.

Next, I added blocks as a "hole" to remove artifacts from the image to svg conversion to clean it up.

Next, i took the inside (white) of the logo and set it as a hole and aligned it to be center of the outside (orange).

Finally, I moved the inside up so it would create a 1mm deep hole in the outside. Then I grouped it all together and exported it.

title: Experimental Delta/Rocstock Extruder with Platform
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a remix of the first Platform mounted Extruder on a Delta/Rostock.
The first one was great how ever didn't have easy access to install the filament in the J-Head/E3D heads.
So I did some research and found www.thingiverse.com/thing:1268424 and used his parts and modified them for my purpose.

7-9-2017: I finally got a new version ready for trial.
So far it has work with no extra vibration or movement. Sits level and doesn't over weight the extruder platform.
I used a compact version of the Nema 17 motor which came off my TronXY X1 Printer.
I've added a video of the print process.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MJpBtYwjeI&t=8s
in the video it will jump in between but it shows the final result.
I still need to fine tune the mount but the results look really great.

description.text:
An afternoon-designed and printed tricopter, designed primarily for Dynam KA22-15M motors (though may fit others, or perhaps many more if you're not afraid of using a drill), a 'standard' 20x40mm servo and a 624 bearing for holding the tail motor (you RepRap builders should have a few of these left :-) )
Shown here mostly assembled, with 10x4.7 propellers attached.

Print out one each of the body, tail arm, tail assembly bracket, tail motor bracket base and tail motor bracket top, and two of the front arms. Attach the arms to the body by slotting them in and driving in M4 screws through the holes provided. Attach the servo and bearing to the tail motor bracket by clamping them in; attach this assembly to the tail assembly bracket, and attach this in turn to the tail arm by driving in some M4 screws in the holes provided.
Note that the tail motor bracket and -top might be hard to print on some printers. I had to make use of Slic3r with support material turned on - this makes these parts come out very well, at the expense of having to do a bit more cleaning.
TODO: Landing gear, and electronics mounting plate! :)

description.text:
Wombot Exilis XL, with 45 degrees corners on glass, which is 250 x 250mm, this clampless corner has adjustment slot underneath.
This might fit some of other wombot family printers, I take No reasonable if it does not fit your printer, so please check before printing.
It should work on existing springs, but I've upgrade to heavy duty springs which requires a 30mm bolts.
Fit all clampless corners on the bed, this place your glass on the bed and adjust all corner squarely to each other.
Note: Place a washer on the underside of this part, as the washer will add more support around the slot.
Once adjusted and fitted you just lift the glass out, with easy.
Print with stand on this edge, a small brim is required.

author: Sarlord

description.text:
This is a replica of the most common alien warship encountered so far. Named the Mk1 initially and thereafter called commonly the eyeship, it has three main gun mounts positioned in a similar design to the aliens eyes. The middle area is believed to be the bridge area but much other information on the ship is still classified. The ship has interstellar capacity and also sublight engines, and carries three very powerful but short ranged meson type beam weapons. All three guns can fire forward so this limits the tactics as they tend to charge into close range and rely on their guns to destroy any target. If they fail to destroy the enemy on the first pass they are vulnerable while they turn to repeat the charge.
The focus of tactics is always to hit their ships at range before they can get in close, but as they always seem to appear in teams of three and can overwhelm a single Federation cruiser. They don't seem to have any dedicated shields but are heavily armoured with a living outer skin which can repair some damage.
Apparently this ship can be crewed by only six aliens, which compared to the hundreds on most Federation ships makes them very vulnerable to boarding and they lack the ability to field even modest shore parties as the Federation can.
It's a spinner, okay.

print_settings.Notes:: The Original Chip-E Base and Top_Plate are being reused.

title: Chip-E Magnetic Quick Disconnect Attachments System

description.text:
Did you ever want to make different fancy gears for your Chip-E? I added quick disconnect 6 ports on original Chip-E robot: 2 dual ports on the shoulder, 1 dual port on the top, 1 single port in front and 2 single ports on the bottom of the feet.
There are various attachments I made so far:
ultrasonic sensor
IR sensor
Laser pointer
Turret
Shoulder joint
Electric Skateboard

And unlimited possibilities for the future servo-based or other kinds of attachments such as:
Gripper
Nerf launcher
Q-tip launcher/Crossbow
TTL controlled headlight
2 channel Remote Control receiver
Segway type balance board
Single leg electric skateboard
or any module that can be powered by 2s battery or 5v.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30

Notes:

The Original Chip-E Base and Top_Plate are being reused.

The Original Chip-E Base and Top_Plate are being reused. The magnetic connectors are modified from BitSnaps. Trim the connectors as shown in the picture and solder the servo cable to the connector. After trimming the connectors should be snug fit to those mounts.
total of 9 pairs of BitSnaps connectors are required.

Material list:
BitSnaps: https://shop.littlebits.cc/products/bitsnaps
Turret servo: 9257 25g servo: https://www.banggood.com/Goteck-GS-9257MG-Metal-Gear-450-Electric-Digital-Servo-p-910493.html
Laser module: 650nm 6mm 5V 5mW Laser: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01ITK4PEO/
IR sensor: Sharp GP2Y0A41SK0F IR Range Sensor: https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/sharp-microelectronics/GP2Y0A41SK0F/425-2819-ND/3884447
Ultrasonic sensor: Parallax PING))) Ultrasonic Distance Sensor: https://www.parallax.com/product/28015

description.text:
Hi Guys,

When I saw the original Design, I wanted to print this directly.
I noticed however after slicing in S3D error in the object. So I started looking for errors with the help of Sketchup. I have found a total of three errors in the height of the fourth window on the front. It took me some time until I found all three errors. With the improvement of the found errors and renewed slices, the further errors have revealed themselves. I have inserted numbers into the photos to clarify where the errors were and in which order they were eliminated.

Many thanks to the designer https://www.thingiverse.com/yuriysklyar/
(Translated with Google)

Hallo Leute,

als ich das Original Design gesehen habe, wollte ich dieses direkt Drucken.
Mir fielen jedoch nachdem Slicen in S3D fehler im Objekt auf. So begann ich mich auf die Fehlersuche mit Hilfe von Sketchup. Ich habe insgesamt drei Fehler in höhe des vierten Fenster auf der Vorderseite gefunden. Es hat etwas gedauert bis ich alle drei Fehler gefunden habe. Mit ausbessern der gefunden Fehler und erneutem Slicen haben sich die weiteren Fehler offenbart. Ich habe Nummern in die Fotos eingefügt, um zu verdeutlichen wo die Fehler waren und in welcher Reihenfolge diese beseitigt wurden.

Großes Dankeschön an den Designer https://www.thingiverse.com/yuriysklyar/

description.text:
Sma and rp-sma mounts . Use m2 screws to tighten them on the standoffs.

These are designed around my quadcopter frame designs Aeolus(Aeolus is atm on prototype and not on the store ) and Hermes but can fit any frame that has standoffs at 30.5mm distance.

https://armattanproductions.com/pages/shop_product_grid/690

The square and hexagon patterns are there in order for the sma to "sink" in and stop it from turning. Usually the vtxs with a soldered sma have square bases and pigtails have hexagon.

In offset and centre versions .

I recommend PETG ,ABS or TPU. I print them with no support.

edit: added a 90 degree mount
edit2 : added 30 degree mount

Enjoy!

description.text:
I travel a lot, and I watch a lot of movies on my iPhone. This stand lets me prop up the iPhone in landscape/portrait mode, and allows adjusting of the iPhone lean angle, especially on the airline seat tray. Once the stand is unfolded into 90 degrees, I can also pull up a couple of magazines from the airline seat pocket, hook the stand onto the magazines using one of 2 available sets of slots (you decide which angle is best for you) and place your iPhone for your own optimal angle. Updated:
This is the fourth iteration so far, and a great new feature: resized to fit iPad as well! - Airline mode works only for iPhone/iPod touch.

• Once printed (both parts), insert a 1.0mm dia metal pin through the stand hinges
  • I am using ABS, and the part\\'s pretty slippery against the iPhone; an easy way to fix this is to get 2 short lengths of heatshrink and shrink them to the two \\'hooks\\'. If you are not sure where, just assemble, prop up your iPhone and it\\'s pretty self-explanatory from there.
    • Just updated sketchup and stl files. Current version prints better, with a stronger hinge that will fit a 1mm dia, rod better. Last update: 26 Apr 2010 for iPad compatibility (Deeper for stability, beveled base for more contact with tables) Please note that the functionality where the ipod/iphone is held when the stand is CLOSED is credited to my friend CopperBlue

Make adjusting your RepRapPro Huxley Z stop easier and more accurate. This simple bracket holds an M3 screw that allows you to use a screwdriver to make easy and accurate adjustments to the Z stop height.
Desinged to be used with RepRapPro Huxley but could easily be used with other machines. The screw bracket is simply glued onto the X idler.
The z-endstop-holder_modified is a modified version of the Endstop holder by Josef Prusa. It is a modified version of the one contained in the RepRapPro Huxley STL files. The OpenSCAD file can be used to make further modifications to suit.

Parts:
1 x z-endstop-holder_modified.stl
1 x easy_adjust_z_stop.stl
3 x M3 20mm machine screws
6 x M3 washers
3 x M3 bolt
1 x spring those found in retractable ball-point pens are ideal Print 1 x z-endstop-holder_modified.stl Attach the z-endstop-holder_modified to the smooth rod of the Huxley and secure with two M3 machine screws, washers and bolts. Screw the z stop switch to the holder. Print 1 x easy_adjust_z_stop.stl Insert an M3 bolt into the slot. (I used a blob of glue to secure it as the slot is purposefully wider than the bolt to allow easier insertion and it moved up and down a little when inserted.) Take one M3 20mm machine screw, place a washer on the screw, then a spring, another washer and then screw into the captured bolt. Glue the easy_adjust_z_stop to the x idler housing. The spring I used was from a discarded retractable ball point pen. The spring was cut in half. Swivel the z-endstop-holder_modified around so the switch arm sits below the screw end. Adjust the screw and the height of the easy_adjust_z_stop so that there is enough travel left in the screw to allow up and down adjustments. Tighten the easy_adjust_z_stop to the smooth rod using its machine screws and bolts.

author: perri

description.text:
Código: 2a931172cf63a0cdcdd9955b221f43b0

El diseño del chasis ha sido realizado con TINKERCAD, una vez ensambladas las piezas en 3D, se han descompuesto para llevarlas a un plano para su exportación a dxf.

Ya en dxf, se han añadido los detalles de personalización del robot y se ha dispuesto para optimizar el tablero de corte.

En la composición final, el robot dispone de los siguientes elementos:

1.- Chasis diseñado con Tintercad, realizado en DM de 3mm, mediante corte por laser.
1.- Rueda loca.
2.- Ruedas motorizadas.
1.- Modulo para gestión de los motores.
1.- Zumbador.
1.- Detector ultrasonidos.
1.- Matriz de led 8x8.
2.- Servos para los brazos.
1.- Modulo sigue líneas.
1.- Modulo para detectar obstáculos.
1.- Modulo comunicación bluetooth
1.- Miniprotoboard dispuesta en el frontal, para facilitar la conexión de distintos módulos.
1.- Arduino nano.

La disposición de los distintos elementos es la que se puede observar en las fotografías adjuntas.

¡Espero que os guste!!!

Referencias

Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es

Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es

Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV

Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

description.text:
Let him/her know your feeling by pushing the button. A 9volt block cell is attached with longer wires, so you can put the battery in some pocket. Resistors are 330 Ohms.
A short sketch makes him smile and wink.
https://youtu.be/ZKaazJybcu4

int Eye = 0; int MouthLow = 2; int MouthHigh = 1; int Switch = A3; int val=0;
void setup() {
pinMode(Eye, OUTPUT); pinMode(MouthLow, OUTPUT);
pinMode(MouthHigh, OUTPUT); pinMode(Switch, INPUT);}
void loop() {
digitalWrite(Eye, HIGH);digitalWrite(MouthLow, LOW);digitalWrite(MouthHigh, LOW);
val=analogRead(Switch);
if (val<200){
for (int x;x<3;x++){
digitalWrite(MouthLow, HIGH); delay(500);
digitalWrite(MouthHigh, HIGH); delay(1000);
digitalWrite(Eye, LOW); delay(200);digitalWrite(Eye, HIGH);delay(200);
digitalWrite(Eye, LOW); delay(200);digitalWrite(Eye, HIGH);delay(200);
digitalWrite(MouthLow, LOW); digitalWrite(MouthHigh, LOW); delay(500); }}}

title: Electronicbox for Bladeless Fan Version 2 by Helix3D

description.text:
Hi,

i build up the Bladeless fan and noticed that there is no case for the electronics.

I made a housing for it and glued it with hot glue on the backside of the housing.

I also added a main switch to the case.

If you don´t want a switch use the closed box, also for those who don´t want a Logo on the cover use the closed one ;)

You need 4x M3 Nuts and M3x16 screws. I heated up the nuts with a lighter and "glued" it in the box. After you glued the electric box on the housing drill a hole in it.

I had to soldering the wires of the speed controller, because they were to short.

I fixed the cable from the power adapter with a cable tie.

title: Updated Z Axis Parts for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
I removed a few of the mounting holes from the top Z-Axis bracket as is was a bit of overkill. I modified the gimble to close the snap in's to be 3.2mm holes. I had trouble finding suitable pins but found 3.2mm concrete nails at the hardware store and cut four 10mm pins from them with a hacksaw. The holes were printed a little smaller than 3.2mm but I hand reamed them with a 3.2mm or 1/4'' drill which made the pins a really snug fit.
This is the most dramatic improvement to my Tarantula, the Z-Axis ridges have completely disappeared! The lower Z Bracket image is printed after the upgrade.
Thanks to thingirob for the original design.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%
I used tinkercad and Fusion 360 to modify this and Simplify3D to slice it.

comments.text: Do you guys have issue with X carriage touching this mount? When i try full 100 X the wheels hit the mount. Looks like I need to modify Z top bracket so I can move mount little to the right ;) Great design. Thanks ;)
comments.author: lvnona

comments.text: No - I don't have this issue.  Works fine for me.
comments.author: lvnona

comments.text: I like this design - it's easy to ream the holes and insert the pins.  I cut 3mm pins from a cotter pin key from HD and it worked really well.  For me, there was no way i could attach the outer ring to the vertical mount with squares that protrude from the ring - it wasn't even close, the legs of the mount would bend.  So I rotated 90 degrees.  I also put Crazy glue inside the holes on the inner ring before inserting the pins, so that it only rotates on the outer axis.  Same thing for the outer ring - I put Crazy glue inside the holes on the outer ring before pushing the pins through and attaching to the mount so that it only rotates on the mount.  Awesome design -  I recommend this to everyone.  I only had very slight z-banding before this upgrade, so little that i wasn't even going to bother.  But after the upgrade, Z is super smooth - amazing design.
comments.author: whoisthis_95

title: Mars Pattern Style Body for Wardog Titan

description.text:
IMPORTANT: I now recommend printing this at a scale of 120% height and width and 127% length. This should give a much better fit with the wardog legs and is very close to the original model, which I have now had the chance to compare mine with.

This is my attempt at creating a version of the body for jdteixeira's Fully posable Wardog Titanic Robot to resemble the Mars Pattern version of the original model that inspired it.

The raised circular parts on the power plants are for the force field generators, the 3mm hole is to allow space for a neodymium magnet to attach them with.

There is a minor indent in the trim of the armour plate on the front section of the centre which was a result of Solidworks being unhappy about creating surfaces properly. If anyone who is better than I am at STL editing programs feels equal to fixing that I'd be very grateful.

Changelog

08/01/2018

Added void shield model

09/07/2017

Immediately noticed front section didn't have a full spherical profile from where I had truncated the centre body. It now does so there is at least a chance of the default head fitting properly.

comments.text: fantastic stuff. I've printed the body today but it seems so small compared to the lucius pattern. is that correct?
comments.author: big_eye

comments.text: I actually recently made some changes to my version of this because a friend bought a Warhound titan and I had the chance to compare the dimensions of my model to his.
comments.author: big_eye

comments.text:
thanks for the reply. clarification though. I use cura so I have a X Y and Z axis. depending on the facing of the parts what is height, width and length changes. what facing do the parts need to have? like when rotated when it's built?
I hope you understand what I'm trying to say.
comments.author: DFCOFFEY

comments.text: Yeah, so by length width and height I'm referring to the dimensions when built. If you orient the parts for printing on the flat faces that they join together at but keep them relatively straight with respect to the axes in Cura, it should be 127% in the Z direction and 120% in X or Y for the centre bits and for the power plants 127% in either X or Y depending on orientation and 120% in the other two.
comments.author: big_eye

comments.text: For the "rear_front" section (the one with the hole that mates to the hip joint), if we rescale the "length" of the piece (as viewed once assembled) to 127% but only rescale the width to 120% won't that make the mounting hole on the bottom oblong/oval? Or is it such a small difference that it doesn't matter? I only ask because I am about to start printing.
comments.author: DFCOFFEY

comments.text: Yeah, it does, but I found that the circular part on the hip joint (the almost cog-like bit at the top) was large enough to cover it, and also that the protruding cylinder from the top of hip joint is a good deal smaller than the hole in the body section that accommodates it, even before scaling. Perhaps that's not the best for a secure glue join, but it's certainly not going to conflict.
comments.author: Beastcave

comments.text: Excellent! Thanks. On the first wardog (jdteixeira's) I printed, I added a metal post to make the groin post taller and drilled out the hole in the body to make it a bit deeper. Worked great and now the body is rotatable yet still secure enough that there is no danger of it falling off the groin.  Will probably do the same for your body when I mate it to a groin.
comments.author: DFCOFFEY

comments.text: That's a good plan. I actually put a pair of neodymium magnets in place so I could take it apart and transport, but honestly a post would be just as effective (and definitely cheaper!)
comments.author: Beastcave

comments.text: Sweet thx! The feet are the right size or do they have to be upscaled too? Also the weapon arms connectors, do they need to be upscaled too 120/120/127 respectively?
comments.author: DFCOFFEY

comments.text: The feet are a good size. Weapon arms I'm not 100% sure on. I've been using the old small ones I printed for mine. My guess would be that they are going to work best at 120% all around to preserve the spherical socket for the arm struts to go in. I will update with more precise info when I have a chance to check the arm span properly, which I feel is the critical feature here for achieving the right look, but for now 120% all around is my recommendation for the arm struts.
comments.author: big_eye

comments.text: I printed the weapon arms at 120% and they fit very nicely on the new body.  However, the round socket for the ball joints is now obviously too big for the standard weapon connectors from jdteixeira's wardog files. I was able to split and then upsize half of the standard connector (one of the two ball-ends) and then stitch the two parts back together in Netfabb, but I lost a bit of overall length in the process... The idea is that the one large ball will fit in the upsized socket of this weapon arm and the other (original sized) ball on the connector will still fit the standard weapons available in jdteixeira's files and the other weapon options available. It is printing now so I'll let you know if that is workable once it is done.

description.text:
This is for my dry box.
some may use it for fun
u can also copy that and do what u want
spins great

U also need:
2 608 bearings
2 m8 nuts
1 150mm m8 rod
2 washers (od=15mm)

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aJaybMc5uyu

to make it easy to assemble I made a bolt out of m8 rod an a nut, usind torch and solder (the total measure with the hat is 150mm). I also glued in place the nut underneath the base. so u put all the components on a bolt and then insert it into the base.

title: Anet A8 Screwdriver Holder / tool holder

description.text:
I wanted somewhere to store the screw drivers that come with the Anet A8, and noticed that the Power Supply on my version has two little slots on the top. Your's may be the same??

So I created this holder and it just slots straight in. Make sure you place the "rounded" edge on the outside to prevent you stabbing your fingers on the edges when getting the screw drivers. Safety first :)

EDIT: Added a V2 which is slighter shallower and not as wide, and with little cut outs in the mounting arms to enable it to push into the slots further.

title: Variable Flat Box Led strip - Boite à flat à ruban LED variable - TS 80/480 - Arduino controlled

description.text:
L’achat d’une boite ou d’un panneau pour réaliser ses flat ne représente pas un coût insurmontable, mais l’intérêt de la faire soit même c’est qu’il est possible de faire du sur mesure et de construire sa boite en fonction de ses propres contraintes.
La boite nécessite de rajouter un ruban à LED.

Les modèles STL fournis sont fonctionels sur mon telescope TS 80/480.
Le diamètre extérieur du tube est de : 104mm.
La boite à flat s'emmanche très bien dans le tube.

Le script OpenScad vous permet de modifier les dimensions de la boite.

Il y a 3 parties à imprimer :

  • la partie intérieure qui est la partie qui s'insère dans le télescope,
  • la partie extérieure qui supporte le ruban à LED.
  • le couvercle pour le transport.

Le pilotage via Arduino de la boite LED est optionnel.

Vous pouvez brancher directement le bandeau LED sur une sortie 5V ou 12V. Cela dépend de votre ruban !

A compilation of parts to build a Prusa clone based on Tom3D's Dolly build.

Original design by Josef Prusa.

author: Estacaco

print_settings.Resolution:: 0.2mm for the tabs, 0.3mm for the spool axis
print_settings.Notes:: Since the internal temperature can reach over 70C, you probably want to print this in ABS or PETG instead of PLA. I used PETG without issues.

description.text:
Made an adapter to use the top cover of a plastic cake carrier commonly available in Canadian and US stores. The original Thing uses EU containers which are difficult to source on this side of the pond.

The top cover I used is the Wilton Cake Caddy: http://www.wilton.com/portable-cake-caddy/2105-9952.html#start=11, available at Walmart, Michaels, etc. I got mine at my local Canadian Tire, along with the Salton VitaPro food dehydrator (which is the same as the original, and the same as what is also sold as a PrintDry).

There is enough room for two full-size spools. I did not try using the dryer as a filament source, presumably you could use the same parts as the original.

Just print 6 of these, slide them over the existing tabs on the trays, and the top of the cake caddy will fit just fine without any air gaps. Use the center piece from the original Thing.

Printer:

ORDBot Hadron

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm for the tabs, 0.3mm for the spool axis

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Since the internal temperature can reach over 70C, you probably want to print this in ABS or PETG instead of PLA. I used PETG without issues.

comments.text:
Thanks a lot for your design. It seems to be the simplest to implement.
Could you please explain what "Dehydrator adapter" is used for?
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text: In the picture it's the 6 orange parts in the bottom of the rim that go over the tabs already present on the trays that come with the dehydrator, and that's what centers the cake bell on it. The seal is not perfect to allow hot air to escape as needed (like the original dehydrator design).

description.text:
A legend modeled only with class A surfaces. (perfect curvatures ans tangeances)

Working time on this model: 2 "big" days so, don't forget to PUSH THE "LIKE" BUTTON If you like, make or download that.
If you want to support my work or just print something very clean, you can download the HIGH DEFINITION STL AND The NATIVE CAD file here :
https://cults3d.com/fr/art/p51-mustang-p51b-5-na

I've also modeled :
P40 Curtis : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1365054

F4U Cosair : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1470382
SR71 A Blackbird : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2396518

------------------------------------------- en français ;-) ------------------------------------

Modélisé suivant d'anciens plans sur logiciel CAO (surfaces de classe A)
Je n'ai pas modélisé tous les détails pour garder uniquement de belle "print lines"

Le STL en HAUTE DEFINITION et le fichier NATIF est dispo ici : https://cults3d.com/fr/art/p51-mustang-p51b-5-na
J'ai travaillé 1.5 jour sur ce modèle. C'est pour ça qu'il n'est pas gratuit sur Cults mais ça m'encouragerai énormément si je pouvais gagner quelques euros pour ce travail ...

Dans tous les cas, un petit clic sur "j'aime" et/ou devenir un de mes followers ne coûte rien et motive vraiment les designers comme moi à mettre leurs modèles en ligne.

author: Nutt

description.text:
Cleaned up CT of a Uromastyx skull.

Some cavity parts remain but most free floating bones have been removed.

Ideally print larger as some parts will be very fragile.

The uploaded file is the best orientation i can see to assist with minimizing support and post print clean up.

Internal bone cavities remain which will show on the pre print slice.

Where possible set slice to keep out side shape and fill internal holes.

Manifolds appear to be intact and no polygon holes.

Check your pre slice first before printing!

title: Creality CR-10 Larger Spool End Cap

description.text:
It seemed that the spool was trying to jump off the cap that came with the spool. I made this one with a larger flange. I used .1 resolution since it has threads.

The original was smaller so the spool could still slip over without taking the cap off and on. I added another version that is larger in case you would like more comfort is knowing it cannot come off.

This is a fidget spinner that's designed to annoy people with an eye for detail:

  • the bearing is off-center
  • the nut traps are off-center
  • one arm is shorter
  • the arms aren't all placed at 120° angles from each other

It's designed to be almost balanced (it would, in theory, be balanced if the 3d-printed portion was weightless) despite all its imperfections.

description.text:
PiSkyScan - in action here https://www.piskyscan.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/pisky1.mp4

A Rasperry Pi Zero project to allow a camera to be remotely pointed any where.
Suitable for CCTV, 3d scanning room scanning, building scanning and hopefully much more.

Pi model B and model 3 versions coming soon.

Build instructions here.

https://www.piskyscan.com/

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Apart from size (145mm x 145mm) should hopefully be a fairly straightforward print.

You need to print bearingCentre and smallGear twice.

The camera holder prints vertically, it needs rework anyway.

Build instructions

Build instructions here https://www.piskyscan.com/

Design

Designed using Blender.

Gears designed with help from http://www.otvinta.com/ (great site for gears in Blender).

Design is coded in Python and then run in Blender to produce the various parts.

description.text:
Fixed STL file of the link below.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2003703

Added: 17/07/22
I've added new 30/60 slots encoders.
You may print these more easily because these files don't require bridging.
If you need 60 slots with bridging one, please let me know in the comment section! :3

The first pic is rendered on Fusion 360.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I've printed this with ABS filament and Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro X.
As you can cleary see, the slots were not printed correctly. Ofcourse, it just didn't work.
If you want to make new encoder, get a higher spec 3D printer :3 (SLA must be the best way)

comments.text:
Yea, probably even such a high manufacturer like Logitech probably wouldn't have micrometer measured motor shaft. So some shaft may differ. And temperature shouldn't be a huge factor in this case, because you can use some super glue and it will hold you for years as there isno friction in this encoder.
I also designed one myself with wider shaft input but that's with 60 slot. I will try to make this with DLP printer when I will get it

A DIFFERENT take on a cooling upgrade. I wanted a larger fan but didn't want to mount it to sides as it doesn't move with the height of the print.

I Designed and 3D printed 4 arms with multi pivot points to allow it to move with effector.

To fit 200mm Cooling fan.

This works like a charm for me, let me know what you think.

author: BMWtech

title: COLEMAN LAY-Z SPA PUMP IMPELLER REPLACEMENT

description.text:
So I inherited a used Coleman lay-z spa recently only when I set it up, filled the tub and went to fire it up I kept getting an E02 warning which doing some research indicated a problem with the water flow. I tried all the troubleshooting techniques but knew it had to be something with the pump. So of course I took it all apart, found the pump underneath and pulled the magnetic impeller out to find the old covering around the magnet had cracked. I then said to myself...self you should be able to repair this plastic casing by designing a new cover for the magnet. So I did, but then I found after I had pressed the new cover over the magnet my assembly was too long or i hadn't pressed the magnet fully in. I measured the face to face distance of the pump insides and found the distance to be roughly 2.25", so I redesigned the impeller to be 1/4" shorter in order to fit.

If you're having trouble with this system as well, give this a shot. I printed the parts 100% infill and using NGEN material. Of course make sure if you attempt this to disconnect the power to the pump and you will also need to disconnect from the hot tub as well in order to flip this unit around and get to the pump on the bottom side of the unit.

comments.text: Do I glue or adhere the magnet to the case and then just set the middle white piece in, then the rotor, then the axle?

These three models show either an empty or full cargo ship in Federation service. The armed cargo ship represents a common cargo ship conversion used for convoy and long range patrol. The armed cargo ship has limited firepower and lacks defense or missile armament, but are still used in less dangerous areas. Many have been fitted with the obsolete laser beam turrets taken from other ships.
Being a cargo ship, the armed cargo ships have excellent range, and are very cheap but should not be used in the line of battle, as has been discovered in the battles around Altair against the Alien menace.
The turrets have no elevation so like many older Federation ships, the whole ship needs to pivot to bring targets under fire.
In times of less tension between the main outbreaks of conflict, many armed cargo ships revert to cargo carrying and have their guns laid up in storage.

title: Mystic Alien (28mm/Heroic scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This character was designed from stats generated on our Wayfarer Random Alien Generator app for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

WAYFARER SPECIES STATS----------------------------------------------------------------------
Mystic Alien (Random alien race)

Step One: Attributes
   Attributes: STR+0 DEX-1 BUL+2 AGI+2 END+0 REA+1 PER-2 WIL+1 CRE+0 CHA-3 

Step Two: Locomotors
   Locomotor: [FOUR-LEGGED] The creature ambulates in the same way as a horse or lion. (Skill Adept (Balance) 2, Skill Adept (Run) 2)

Step Three: Manipulators
   Manipulator: [ARMS] The creature possesses a pair of arms and may manipulate objects. (No adjustment)

Step Four: Extra Adaptions
   Adapation: [TRUNK] The creature's snout is elongated into a prehensile trunk. (-4 DEX when using the trunk as a manipulator, Acute Sense (Scent) 4)
   Adapation: [PRIMITIVE] The creature is relatively bestial or even non-sapient. (REA -1, Acute Sense (Scent) 9, Skill Adept (Fieldcraft) 9, Openness -2)

Step Five: Personalities
   O.C.E.A.N.: Openness+4 Conscienctiousness+0 Extroverison+4 Agreeableness+1 Neuroticism+0

description.text:
This thing is an easy power supply box for some 12V 10A power supplies. I designed this because I didn't find any existing thing for this PSU, which I ordered as a replacement for the stock PSU of my TronXY X1 3D-printer.

Does this Design Work for my PSU?

It's very easy to find out whether this design works for you. Scroll down to learn more!

Other Requirements

You'll need additionally:

  • 8 12mm long M3 screws
  • 4 M3 nuts
  • An inlet with optional switch and fuse, like
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Red-Light-Power-Rocker-Switch-Fused-IEC-320-C14-Inlet-Power-Socket-Fuse-Switch-Connector-Plug/32679674596.html

Printer:

TronXY X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm (2/10)

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

The core part can be printed as shipped with the file, while I recommend laying down both the top and the additional pair of feet for easier printing.

Assembly

The assembly is very easy, you'll need to:

  1. Print all parts
  2. Mount the inlet plug onto the frame
  3. Wire everything up
  4. Fix the main enclosure part on the PSU with the two screws on the back
  5. Add the additional feet on the PSU with the other two screws on the back
  6. Put on the top by putting in nuts in the spacings and screw everything in
I used tinkercad for every extent of the design process.

If your PSU is an XD-120-12, you're good to go!
I bought mine here: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00UEUWN06

For any other PSU, stick to the following:
The three limiting factors are the width, height and screw positions.

Lay down the PSU in the same orientation and position as shown in the upper image. While the total length (left to right on the image) doesn't matter, the width (top to bottom on the image) does: It has to be at most 100mm for the design to work.

The height, on the other hand, must not exceed 45mm!

The last crucial factor is the alignment and distance between the screw holes. The design supports 80mm hole distance only!

print_settings.Notes:: Note: The movable arm could use a drop of oil (yes oil, not WD40). Not much, so it does not drip out but enough to make it move smoothly.

title: WaveShare 5inch Display Housing and Display Mount

description.text:
NOTE: Before printing please check, if it looks sane for you! Some of the models around thingiverse seem to have been designed for a different version of the display. My display and my Raspberry did not fit into those housings, so I designed this one.

This model contains a housing that fits a WaveShare 5inch Display (Version 2) including a Raspberry PI 3.

The project contains two versions of the model:

  • normal box without a mount
  • housing with a "wall mount" with a movable arm

I use the second version to mount a Raspberry PI running Pronterface mounted to my printer-housing.

The movable arm allows routing cables inside the arm. It is basically possible to also route the power-supply inside the arm, but I still need to solder micro-usb connector that is small enough to fit into the housing.

To close the housing, I used the spacers included in the WaveShare package including addidional M3 screws for the front-plate. The arm is fixed with M3.5 metal screws. Those can be easily removed to allow access to the USB and ethernet-ports of the Raspberry PI.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

The archive contains a model with and without a mount. The model without the mount only consists of the bottom and top part. The top part is also used for the model including the mount. Please ensure that you look at the files before printing and be sure that you rotate them properly.

For only the display case print

  • WaveShare_5inch_Bottom.stl
  • WaveShare_5inch_Top.stl

For the box including the mount, print

  • WaveShare_5inch_Top.stl
  • WaveShare_Mount_5inch_Bottom.stl
  • WaveShare_Mount_5inch_Mount_Top.stl
  • WaveShare_Mount_5inch_Mount_Plate.stl

I used slic3r for slicing. During the print I used white ABS. To ensure that the round parts came out nicely, I had to manually tune the support material settings.

The wall mount prints best, if printed on the side to ensure that the round parts are completely circular.

Note: The movable arm could use a drop of oil (yes oil, not WD40). Not much, so it does not drip out but enough to make it move smoothly.

title: Flexy-Hand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A proof of concept printable hand with "live hinge" flexible joints. Individually activated fingers using Filaflex filament as tendons.
Printed in Makerbot Translucent Red and Filaflex hinges.
Re-mix this idea into your own robotic or prosthetic project.
  • Fingers open automatically, no return tendons or springs needed.
  • "Frictionless" articulation - no rubbing parts.
  • Stretchable tendons offering adaptive grip on irregular objects (only one motor required to activate all fingers).
  • Fully printable solution, no vitamins required.
  • Tough and rugged.
  • Realistic form under a surgical glove (see images).
    • Video here : http://youtu.be/K8mtqPTJ-Ys
    Video review here : http://youtu.be/Z70YWNuOB8E Thanks to 3DUniverse.org and jesimon
    Here is an article about the Flexy-Hand on 3DPrint.com
    My 1st printed Flexy-Hand (above) is now on display in the iMakr Store, London.
    .
    EDIT 19/03/2014 : Added an "Opposable Thumb" version of the body.
    EDIT 24/09/2014 : Added "Ring Pull.stl" so you can attach to the tendons to make it easier to pull them, see one of the images.
    EDIT 16/08.2014 : Added two mounting holes in the base of the Hand for attachment to rigs/arms/boxes etc.
    EDIT 29/07/2014 : Increased the tendon hole diameters in the fingers from 2mm to 3mm when printed at full scale. To help printing at smaller scales.
    EDIT 16/07/2014 : Put hole in base of finger hinge (7.stl) so that it can be inserted into hand body easier.
    EDIT 07/07/2014 : Updated the profile of the base hinges for the fingers (7.stl). This new profile, requires less force to close the fingers, yet it is shaped to better aid finger return.
    EDIT 19/05/2014 : Due to Janfigueroa request, added hands (LH/RH) with a more opposable thumb for better grip, print the same fingers for either hand body, The tendons exit the base in this version in a circular pattern instead of a line.
    EDIT 06/05/2014 : Two part mould for hinges uploaded from my remix here.
    EDIT 02/05/2014 : Right Hand uploaded along with it's fingers.
    EDIT 12/03/2014 : After many requests, I have uploaded a STEP file of the hand body (6 - 45deg Thumb Step File.zip)
    EDIT 09/03/2014: There has been some confusion regarding how much articulation the fingers have. I have uploaded 3 photos, which show the thumb touching the first two fingers and very close the the ring finger also. I have also uploaded a plate of fingers (yum yum) for anyone who wants to print them all off in one go.
    .
    http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
    http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print hand body without support.
Print finger segments either vertically (as modelled) or horizontally with support.
Print Hinges segments without support.
Assemble according to PDF

I modelled for Filaflex which is more elastic than Ninjaflex and other flexible PLA atm. However Ninjaflex does work but it maybe a little harder to assemble hence the hinges that fit into the hand body may need a little extra persuading with a screwdriver etc, maybe with some lubrication that can be washed away, e.g. liquid soap. I printed hinges with no infill and 2 or 3 perimeters (depends on scale) using Slic3r, this makes them nice and "spongy" adjust this if you want stiffer or more flexible hinges. The hinges at the base of the fingers are assembled a certain way round to aid finger return, please see section image to show this. Any issues getting the base hinges in can also be helped by using a craft knife and trimming a little off either the hinge or the body of the hand, YMMV
You can also cast your own with silicon sealant using the Hinge Mould which I also include here for completeness.

Pre-stretch a length of 1.75mm Filaflex filament till it wont elongate any more, this reduces it's thickness. This stuff is so strong, I have yet to snap it. Feed each end through the two filament holes in the end of the finger tip. Both ends of the filament should come out of the same hole in the base of the finger tip part (see section image plus photo). Tie off in a none slip knot (left over right then right over left) and snip off one of the excess strands. If tensioned correctly the knot should hide itself in the base hole of the finger tip. Thread the tendon down through the finger segments out of the base of the hand.

My question is now, which silicon did you use?
Best Regards Richard
comments.author: DonNeo

comments.text:
Hi,
As mentioned I printed the hinges in Filaflex so I have not used Ninjaflex or the Silicon casting process. However I believe others have used Dragon Skin 30, Silcoflex and Latex with success, although it is not as strong as printed Filaflex. This is due to the fact that a printed hinge has lot of little crack arrestors within the grain of the print, whereas with the cast version, a crack/split once started can quickly propagate through the hinge, causing it to fail.
