comments.text:
Hi to all Flexi hand followers!!!
I printed this hand with a Rep 2. It came out perfect!!! ... almost no fixing necessary. For the joints i used Nylon 645 at 0% infill, works Great!!!! But i have two small changes i wish someone can make to this hand.
First, the idea of individual channels for each finger is great!!!. I think it will be better if those channels exits the palm as a circle instead of the actual lined-up configuration. Having those exits centered make the hand closer the the real hand (Carpal Tunnel) and makes it easier to make a wrist with movement for attaching it to a forearm.
Second, in another comment a guy asked for splitting the palm in parts to let the thumb one more degree of movement. I settle for fixing the thumb in a position that when flexed, it comes opposite of the index or middle finger, like a claw. That way keeps the hand close to the original design but enables to grasp round things like soda cans and glasses.
Thanks to gyrobot for this thing and to anyone that implements my suggestions.

title: Helping Hands Operator - Automatic Soldering Tool by Yuval Dascalu

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yf_CHN6EXmc

This is my official entry for the Chip-E Remix Challenge.
For this challenge I made a device which uses almost all of the original components and uses the original files to some degree.

The device connects to your arm and contains 3 motors, an LCD 2x16 display and the Geekduino / Arduino Uno.

This device is intended to be used in situations in which you cannot use the typical Helping Hands like when not faced with a proper table or when you need you work high up or near the ground, as had happen to me time and time over the course of last year.

Now I do understand it isn't really a remix of the body of the Chip-E, but after consulting with RobotGeek they wrote to me that "If you feel inspired to use the parts in the Chip-E Kit toward another style of robot or machine, feel free to throw it in the competition, we'd love to see it! As much as we would like for people to modify Chip-E as a walking/dancing/goofin robot, we're well aware that the RobotGeek parts included in the kit are quite versatile and could be configured into entirely different machines.".
I based my design with that in mind.

All parts may need to be scaled up by x10
All the parts in the following pictures that are Purple are 3D printed
Code: https://pastebin.com/sF8TZsJ2
All electronics parts are sold at the following link: https://goo.gl/oy1N6q

Printer Brand:

PrintrBot

Resolution:

~1.2

Infill:

~10%

Notes:

In the Steel Wool part you are required to use supports, see the explanation about that for more information.

In the spool part no supports are needed.

Typical cleanup with the exception of the Steel Wool

In the Steel Wool part you are required to remove the supports in another way, see the explanation about that for more information.

Programs used

Inventor 2018
Cura
Arduino

Rod Holder Explanation

The part itself has 2 interesting parts.
1) Connecting to the metal sheet part is done by wrapping around the object instead of using the built in holes. There is not particular advantage to doing so, I wanted to explore what I could do and it resulted in an extremely stable connection.
2) The part holding the Soldering iron is as thick as the traction pads provided in the original kit (20 mm). The shape of that side of the part is an octagon which houses the traction pads in a way that leaves roughly 20 mm between the traction pads. I chose that number because it seems to be a rather average size between and Soldering irons I came across with. This shape has the additional advantage that it can change it's shape. If the Soldering iron is larger then 20 mm than the pull of the printing material will hold the iron in place, just like in the video presented, in which the iron was secures so tightly it wouldn't nudge at all, even when met with alarming force. If the iron is smaller than 20 mm than a simple 4 mm screw can be used alongside a 4 mm nut to hold the iron in place. I could not find any iron that would fit that criteria but I still left it as an option.

Joint Shoe Explanation

This design is the file "Right Shoe". It was not tempered with at all.

Spool Explanation

This part should not require any supports. I used 1 mm wide soldering wire I found at my local hardware store. In order to spool it correctly, insert the wire into the hole in the spool and lock it in place at the other side by turning it 90 degrees. After you do that continue to spool the wire clockwise (if the hole connecting to the motor is facing you). When all of that is done simply fit the rest of your solder up the straw.
Also on the same site where you can purchase all of the other motors and electronics, you can get a servo without the 180 degree limitation with the same measurements. If you cannot open up the motor you have and remove the limitation I would suggest you purchase the free-spin motor. If you are unable to do both, feel free to un-spool the solder material after each period.

Steel Wool Holder Explanation

When this part is printed, make sure the plane facing the printing surface is the plane with the letter "S" all about. Don't expect at all that the "S" parts will print out well, don't waste your time on that. The idea is after it is printed with supports, you remove them by the top, leaving the bottom of it all sharp and messy. That way it can be used as a form of physical adhesive with the steel wool. Personally I like adding some glue to the area, but that is up to you.
I went to my local market and got a small pack of Steel wire, intended for dishes for about 1.5$ and I cut it with a piece with a pair of scissors, I wrapped all of the loose fibers around the main part of the wool and it held on great, way better than expected. In order to connect the piece to the sheet metal, insert it the in top 2 holes and try and jam one of the provided thin screws in the holes I made, once I added them both it never came close to coming off.

Brace Explanation

This is the largest part in my gadget, so let's break it down a little bit.
1) The motor connections: For that part I took the connection RobotGeek used in their Shoe design, simple and elegant. I mirrored them and added them to my chassis.
2) The electrical board connections: I really enjoyed that part, and the more I like using screws, the less I like using nuts to hold them in place. I used the electrical spacers added in the kit, and made Hex shaped holes that are slightly larger. You are meant to slide the spacers into the holes and if the connection is not tight enough, apply a tiny amount of superglue. Now that you've done that you can simply screw the electrical board in place. I really enjoyed that part.
3) The battery and On/Off switch connections: both of them easily slide into place, turned out better than expected.
4) Strap connections: Despite how well this part turned out, I still regret it's not printable. I went to my local outdoors shack and got myself some 24 mm wide silicon straps, anything thicker, larger or smaller should would just as well. I am well aware that those straps are not the same size everywhere in the world, that's why I made them adjustable, tried to make up for it.

Straw Explanation

The straw is the last part of my gadget, and still one of my favorites. To begin it has a flat side, which rests on top of the brace. The reason the straw is not a part of the chassis is only due to the size of my printer. Although in hindsight, there's nothing stopping you from inserting something as small as a piece of paper in one of the sides of the flat area to make up for different types of Soldering Irons. This part was the most difficult part to sketch and the most enjoyable at the same time. A lot of thinking went into the curve of it all until I figured it out.
The straw has 2 areas which are thinner than the usual; they are meant to provide walls for the zip ties which hold it in place. the zip ties are present in the kit we are given. The zip ties connect through the the Strap holes as shown in the picture below.

https://goo.gl/f2uzN9

description.text:
Everyone else is designing fidget spinners, so I thought that I'd take a shot at it.

This is a simple two arm fidget spinner designed in FreeCAD.

You should be able to print it out as-is. The two photos showing the spinner in action and the spinner sitting still were printed directly from the .stl with no scaling. The bearings used in the spinner were 608zz which apparently go in Roller Skates. These also seem to be the bearings that everyone else is using for fidget spinners. The Amazon ASIN for the specific product that I bought is B071CQRNHL (just paste that into the amazon search bar)

To get the exact results from my photo, print the spinner along with 5 plugs and 1 stand.

The github URL for the FreeCAD file is here: https://github.com/rl337/freecad/tree/master/fidgets/two-arm-prototype

title: Soporte hotend Argento V6 para p3 steel cordobesa

description.text:
Soporte para hotend argento v6 para el carro original de la cordobesa (hay que sacarle el soporte de hotend que trae).

description.text:
This stackable tower for the Victor 888 or 884 speed controller can be stacked to any height, and features a PWM clip, strain relief holes for zip ties, and 3/4" of clearance for airflow. Secure the whole thing together with skinny threaded rod for additional robustness.  
It can be used for Talons, but if you aren't using the fans, it's rather tall.

To make this tower you'll need, per speed controller: One bottom mount,
One side stack,
One side stack with clip, To complete the tower, you'll also need:
One more bottom mount (to serve as the "lid" for swarf protection).
Four bottom connectors (one for the bottom plate, one for the top).
Two connectors for each "story" of your tower. The tower snaps together, but we highly recommend securing the whole thing with two small threaded rods (which you can also use for mounting).

title: Basic double pendulum
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tired of your fidget spinners ? Use their bearings to build a cool double pendulum !

This contraption demonstrates the theory of chaos which can be said of a system that is extremely sensitive to initial conditions (tje wheather is a good example of this theory as well)
This basicaly means in this case that if you swing the pendulum with a slightly different initial placement of the arms, you will get a completely different pattern !

This build uses 4 standard 608z roller skate bearing (typically used today in hand spinners), a 2020 aluminium extrusion (you can use any 20mm20mm pole that you can find), and a base that fits your needs (mine is a 360200*18mm pine base, the heavier the better).
You will also need washes and screws to prevent the arms from falling of.
The middle part fits between the to arms.

Have fun !

Anet A8

The original file / part allowed a horizontal phone to tip forward and perhaps fall. I wouldn't want that to happen, so made a small modification. New version is: "phone dock V2.stl". ===================
I made a couple of minimalist phone stands for a new phone but wanted more stability, and came up with this monstrosity. It won't win any beauty contests but does the job. Viewing angle is 30 degrees.

remixed_from.author: MaddeMichael
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Rear Sensor Mount for TronXY Style Sensor w/ Height Screw STOCK EXTRUDER

title: [V2] Anet A8 Rear Sensor Mount for TronXY Style Sensor w/ Height Screw
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is marked as WIP in case I need to add more photos, update instructions or tweak the files. This thing still prints and works pretty well though!

As before, this mount is designed for the "Practical 6 - 36V Auto Leveling Sensor for 3D Printer". I made it because I couldn't find any rear mounts for this sensor that I was satisfied with.

This is a new version of my rear sensor mount for stock/TronXY sensors for the Anet A8.
The old one was alright, but was too low for an E3D carriage and twisted a lot, so I improved it. It's more stable and, although it's a little bigger, it also looks better.

This one has a little bit of give, depending on how well your printer prints, but not enough to be a problem. It is assembled in virtually the same way as the old one, but uses two less screws as one part has been removed entirely.

Advantages of this include:

  • Much lighter than the acrylic hunk that comes with the sensor
  • Sensor height can be adjusted with much higher precision using a screw and spring, without updating firmware or hoping you've kept it steady while tightening screws
  • Sensor is out of the way of the nozzle, allowing a good view of prints
  • Does not displace the fan at all, so you don't have to worry about whether your duct is in the right position
  • It's compatible with most other custom X-carriages as it doesn't mount directly to them

This thing is comprised of 3 files, but you only need two:

  • SensorBlockUniversal - this is the bit the sensor fixes to - you need this piece
  • ScrewBlockE3D OR ScrewBlockStock - You only need one of these. You need to use ScrewBlockE3D if you use the E3D carriage by ATS or similar, or you need to use ScrewBlockStock if you're using the stock carriage

The reason the E3D carriage requires a different ScrewBlock is that it raises the hotend nozzle too high up for the stock mount to work. However, it is possible that Volcano hotends will still need the ScrewBlockStock part!

NOTE: I haven't tested the E3D block properly, as I accidentally broke the hotend. Oops. It should still work based on how it was designed though!

Important Settings to change in Configuration.h:
Stock nozzle position:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 18
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 60
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 40
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 180
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 180
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 60

E3D Nozzle Position:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 60
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 40
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 180
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 180
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 60

Either way, you must ensure that AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS is set to 3, like this:
#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 3
(Thanks, niftymaker!)

Things you need:

  • The 3D printed parts you need for your carriage
  • A screwdriver
  • 2 M3*12 screws - you can get a way with shorter, but longer could be a problem
  • 1 M3*30 screw OR an M3*20 screw - 30 allows you to lower the sensor more
  • An M3 nut
  • A pen spring - not necessary, but helps keep the sensor down
  • The Autolevelling sensor and the M3 screws and nuts it comes with

Sorry about some of the photos! I've tried a little post-processing to tidy them up a bit, but I'm still getting used to the distance this camera is focuses at.

I'm pretty new to 3D printing, so if you have any tips, I'd love to hear them!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The parts are already oriented best for printing.

The SensorBlockUniversal does not need supports, but if you struggle with bed adhesion a brim may help as it prints tall.

Both of the ScrewBlocks need support - I used the concentric pattern in Cura at 25% - it worked wuite well and was pretty easy to remove - just be careful not to break off the plastic "plugs" while removing support!

First, clean up the prints!

You're going to want to remove stringing, blobs, lips created by printing too close to the bed, and any other surface defects. You may want to sand the parts a little if they don't fit in each other properly.

It's also worth sliding the parts together by hand a little bit to smooth them up. Assembly

I'm just going to put the assembly instructions in images and captions, to keep this fairly straghtforward!

First, you need either ScrewBlockStock or ScrewBlockE3D and 2 M3*12 screws You then need to plug the ScrewBlock you need into the top half of the lower linear bearing. Be careful not to break the plugs! - Orientation does matter! The two prongs next to the middle screwhole (where my thumb is) must point down on both ScrewBlocks. Screw the M3 screws into the plug holes - the little plugs (that you didn't break) are then squeezed against the inside of the bearing holes, locking the part into place. Next we assemble the sensor mount - this uses the sensor, the screws and nuts it arrives with and SensorBlockUniversal The nuts go here on the back (where the slot is visible along with two nice M3 nut shaped gaps) And screw the sensor on like this - you might need to screw it on higher or lower (depends on you carriage - I have it as low as possible on stock) - Just make sure it is super tight so it doesn't drop on its own Next, you need to stick a nut in the bottom. If you can't get it in, you can try to tighten it in with a screw, or maybe heat it up to insert it (I didn't do that). If it's too loose, that isn't a problem - the spring counteracts that - just hold it in place until it is screwed in Finally, you can stick it all together - this just requires a long screw and the (optional) spring Insert the screw into the screwhole and slide the spring onto it (then apply a bunch of Post-Processing effects to the photo) Then slide the two parts together, being careful to hold the nut from earlier in place, and screw them together And it's fully assembled! Remember to take a nice pic and post it in the "I Made One" thing! Getting the height right!

To adjust the height of the sensor to what I needed, I lowered the hotend until the nozzle had decent friction on some paper. From there, you just need to lower the sensor until the light comes on (While the printer is on, otherwise no light will ever come on). If the light is already on at startup, raise the sensor up first before lowering it again.

Then just do a few test prints - if the nozzle starts too high, raise the sensor a little, if it starts too low and scrapes the bed, lower the sensor a little. Do this by small screw turns until it's correct.

Turning the screw anti-clockwise lowers the sensor. Turning it clockwise raises the sensor.

Modelled and exported from Blender!

Ah, Blender, my good friend. The interface completely sucks, but it doesn't have many limits.

This used the file from my old sensor mount, just modified a bunch. I use the MeasureIt plugin to keep sizes correct, and set up my scene in millimeters and set the grid bounds to appear as a "virtual print bed".

Lot's of tweaks and boolean modifiers later, we have this.

Stability Blocks

This version, compared to the old, does not have the "stability blocks" that reduce the amount the sensor can move up and down. The actual reason for this is that I accidentally removed them without noticing.
Instead of re-adding them, I figured it makes a little bit more sense to allow you to adjust a small amount of height via the sensor screws if you absolutely need to, so I left it as is.

title: Raspberry PI (OctoPI) Controlled Power Console for 3D Printer

description.text:
I wanted to make a power control box similar to the one built by Jeffeb3 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428478) to control my Prusa i3 and lighting via OctoPi, however I wanted to use all 4 relays on the Sainsmart relay control board, and also wanted 2 always-on outlets. I also did not want to colocate the Raspberry PI 3B inside the power board, instead opting for repurposing a CAT5 cable to carry TTL signals from the Pi to the power control box. All of my code was based on Jeffeb3's work, please look at his Thing for completing that portion of the build (just duplicate commands for the other 2 relays.)

The power control box was designed in FreeCAD. This was my first time designing something in FreeCAD, any constructive feedback is welcome.

The Sainsmart relay board is secured to the bottom of the box with 4 M3x5 screws. The top is secured with 4 M3x10 screws. I had to use a drill to ream out the holes to get a better fit, the uploaded design incorporates changes that should make this unnecessary.

The power cord was purchased from Lowes, and is a 14/3 cord. I used a drill to open up the power cable hole to match the size of the cord. It is secured in place with two-part epoxy. If I were to do it again I would build in some strain relief into the bottom section of the box.

Internal wiring was a mix of 16 and 18 gauge wire which I had on hand. The TTL signals are carried by jumper wires with Dupont connectors on one end.

The top was printed in two phases by pausing the print and swapping filament in my Prusa i3 Mk2.

Matching up the GPIO outputs from the OctoPi to the wires in the power control box took longer than it should have and quite a bit of trial and error. Turns out the cable was labeled as a 568B cable, but it was actually a 568A cable. I used Dupont connectors to connect to the OctoPi. (https://acuitysupport.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/article_attachments/203181108/T568-1.png)

Parts used and links to them are below.
Jumper Wires: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01L5ULRUA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
RJ45 Connector: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IO3HB2K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Dupont Crimp Connectors: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B014YTPFT8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Crimping Tool:https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OMM4YUY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Sainsmart Relay: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0057OC5O8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

comments.text: I had an idea for something almost exactly like this as a "someday I'll design this" - and I see you've done it already, even down to the "always on". Agreed with ElmoC about the fuse, will integrate that into my print. Beautiful job on this, I will be making mine soon!

author: rowdyyates115

description.text:
This is a case for Silicon Lab's Thunderboard Sense board

I've designed this to use the sensors of the board outdoors, but I did not test it yet.
Features:

  • Venting hole above the temperature/humidity and the air pressure/temperature sensors. The holes are going upwards to the sensor to avoid water getting in
  • 5.3mm hole above the light sensor
  • Drain holes at the bottom to remove water possibly getting into the case and to let air circulate
  • Hanger

Other parts needed:

  • 5mm or 1/5 inch acrylic/plexiglass rod, cut down to size and polished (e.g. with a dremel), and glued into the hole
  • 7mm M2 pan-head screw to mount the board
  • 14mm M3 flat-head screw to attach the parts

Battery is replaceable if the board is mounted in the case just by removing the back, but the USB port is not accessable.

author: jesienazareth

description.text:
These are parts to a greenhouse watering system I am currently trialling in my greenhouse. It consists of a ring around the greenhouse constructed from garden hose, held to the greenhouse by clips that friction lock into the channels in the uprights by inserting and twisting. Short lengths of hose are connected by T-pieces That allow water supply to be tapped off to 6mm OD (Outside Diameter), 4mm ID (Inside Diameter) piping (that I had from a cheap shop bought drip watering system that I really didn't get on with). I believe the piping I have is made from vinyl.

In addition to the clips and T-pieces, files for corner pieces and an end piece are also available. The corner pieces allow the hose to be more neatly routed around the corners of the greenhouse without kinking the hose. The end piece has a connector on the end of it to allow 6mm OD tubing to be connected, but a thin wall is left in the design so that this is optional - drill out with a 4mm drill to use.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Due to the nature of the parts, there doesn't seem to be a good way to print most of these pieces without supports. I printed mine flat and cut/filed the barbs into a sensible after the barb support material was removed.

Additionally I used a 6mm drill to ensure the inside of the connector for the 6mm OD tubing was round and smooth.

I printed the clips without supports. The clips were designed to be the same width as that of the width of the T slot in the greenhouse. The head of the T connector that holds the clips to the frame is designed with 2 curved edges to facilitate the clips to be inserted in the the T slots and rotated 90 degrees to lock them in place. These edges were lightly filed to ensure that they could be twisted into the T slots.
